prompt:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
For API StringTokenizer.nextToken, the API usage rule is: Create a StringTokenizer with a specified string and delimiter, and then obtain the next token as long as there are more tokens available.

Question: Java: Handling browser's request in my ProxyServer: :I am writing ProxyServer, firstly I use ServerSocket to get Socket that is connected to me. Then I get InputStream from connected Socket and readed it. I have outputted the request of my browser to console:GET http://mail.ru/ HTTP/1.1Host: mail.ruProxy-Connection: keep-alive Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko)Chrome/31.0.1650.63 Safari/537.36Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate,sdchAccept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4Cookie: p=7nkAAOS6hAAA; mrcu=7D86524D326C5CB36F898F4A4CD9;_ga=GA1.2.1174941236.1388398432; c=PCwPUwAAAPKbAAAiAgAAcQAAz5QIAgAA;I must create new Socket to write this request to internet, but Socket needs port number and hostname(String) to connect. If we consider that port number is always 80 then from what part of this request I must get hostname? Is this GET http://mail.ru/ HTTP/1.1 or Host: mail.ru? Also, can I just send to internet only GET http://mail.ru/ HTTP/1.1 abandoning other parts?Last question is, should I have to rewrite this GET method itself?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:
response:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: 
String request = "GET http://mail.ru/ HTTP/1.1\nHost: mail.ru\nProxy-Connection: keep-alive\nAccept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8\nUser-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko)Chrome/31.0.1650.63 Safari/537.36\nAccept-Encoding: gzip,deflate,sdch\nAccept-Language: ru-RU,ru;q=0.8,en-US;q=0.6,en;q=0.4\nCookie: p=7nkAAOS6hAAA; mrcu=7D86524D326C5CB36F898F4A4CD9;_ga=GA1.2.1174941236.1388398432; c=PCwPUwAAAPKbAAAiAgAAcQAAz5QIAgAA;";
StringTokenizer tokenizer = new StringTokenizer(request, "\n");
String firstLine = tokenizer.nextToken();
String hostLine = tokenizer.nextToken();
String[] hostLineParts = hostLine.split(" ");
String hostname = hostLineParts[1];

<<<explanation>>>: 
To get the hostname from the request, you can use StringTokenizer to split the request into lines. The first line contains the request method, URL, and HTTP version. The second line contains the "Host" header, which specifies the hostname. You can split the second line by spaces and get the second part, which is the hostname. In this case, the hostname is "mail.ru". 

You cannot just send the "GET http://mail.ru/ HTTP/1.1" line to the internet. The request must include all the necessary headers, such as "Host", "User-Agent", "Accept", etc. These headers provide important information to the server and are required for proper communication.

You do not need to rewrite the GET method itself. The GET method is a standard HTTP method and does not need to be modified.
